item.source: Parse a text file into a Class file?

item.title: Parse a text file into a Class file?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

zyle1992:

I think I get it, but I’m not 100%. Could you explain it a bit more?

java.lang.reflect.Method represents a physical method inside of a class file, such as my[tt]handleButton()[/tt] above. Calling ButtonHandler.class accesses the public java.lang.Class of the specified class file. java.lang.Class is a reflective representation of a Java class file. You can use java.lang.Class to get the declared fields and methods of a Java class file, as well as access their values and invoke them.

When accessing a reflective java.lang.reflect.Field or java.lang.reflect.Method, you must provide an instance for it, unless it’s static. Take a look at the following Java code:

ButtonHandler.handleButton();

The above code can be achieved by doing the following:

Class<?> buttonHandlerClass = ButtonHandler.class; // represents the ButtonHandler class
Class<?>[] argumentTypes = new Class<?>[0]; // this represents the Java class types of the arguments of the method, such as String.class; this array is empty because our method has no arguments
Method handleButton = buttonHandlerClass.getDeclaredMethod("handleButton", argumentTypes); // retrieves the 'handleButton' reflective representation for the button handler class
Object[] arguments = new Object[0]; // these are the respective arguments to the argument types specified above. For example, if the method had a String argument, then this array must contain a String object respective to the String.class type in the argumentTypes array. Note that this array is also empty because our method has no arguments.
Object returnVal = handleButton.invoke(null, arguments); // calls/invokes handleButton() from a static context (the null argument denotes a static context). If you would like to access a method from a virtual context, you can do so by providing an instance to that class in place of null (an instance such as 'Object someObject = new Object()', where someObject is the instance
// note that 'returnVal' is the value returned by handleButton. A value is always returned, even if the method invoked has the return type of void

Hopefully you understand a little more about reflection with this brief overview. Reflection isn’t the easiest thing to pick up at first, but it is considerably useful.

Read full topic

item.source: Parse a text file into a Class file?

item.title: Parse a text file into a Class file?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:21, topic:288467”]Thanks, BLOBs worked perfectly

Oh, one more thing. How would I make it execute just a single method? Let’s say that(Sorry for the RSPS reference…) I wanted to delete an item from a players inventory, when they clicked a certain button.

Hashtable<Integer, Script> scripts = new Hashtable<Integer, Script>();//Integer is the ID of the button they clicked, Script is the method/methods to call when the button is pressed.

public static boolean startScript(int buttonID) {
    if(scripts.get(buttonID) == null) {
        System.out.println("No listener for button " + buttonID + " registered.");
        return false;
    }
    scripts.get(buttonID).execute();//Let's say that for now, every button does System.out.println(buttonID);
    return true;
}

Or something along those lines, without having to program every function into it. Basically, how could I do something like this, and make it extensible?[/quote]

Well, there is an easier way of doing that. You can use java.lang.reflect.Method to store declared methods you wish to invoke. But unless you store the instances of classes you wish to call instance methods from, you need the invoked methods to be static.

For example, you could do the following:

import java.lang.reflect.Method;
import java.util.Hashtable;

public class ButtonExecutor {

	private ButtonExecutor() { // allow no instances of this class
	}

	private static Hashtable<Integer, Method> assignments;

	public static void registerButton(int buttonId, String methodName, Class<?> methodParent) throws Exception {
		Method method = methodParent.getDeclaredMethod(methodName, new Class<?>[0]);
		assignments.put(buttonId, method);
	}

	public static boolean executeButton(int buttonId) throws Exception {
		if (!assignments.containsKey(buttonId)) {
			System.err.println("No assignment for button " + buttonId + ".");
			return false;
		}
		assignments.get(buttonId).invoke(null, new Object[0]);
		return true;
	}

	static {
		assignments = new Hashtable<Integer, Method>();
	}
}

An example of using this class:

public void handleButtons() {
	int buttonId;
	// ...
	try {
		boolean status = ButtonExecutor.executeButton(buttonId);
		// ...
	} catch (Exception e) {
		e.printStackTrace();
	}
}

public void registerButton(int buttonId) {
	ButtonExecutor.registerButton(buttonId, "handleButton", ButtonHandler.class);
}

ButtonHandler.java:

public class ButtonHandler {

	public static void handleButton() { // must be static and have no arguments; return type does not matter
		// ...
	}
}

If I’m too vague here, I can explain the above in far more detail if you want.

Read full topic

item.title: Parse a text file into a Class file?
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Thanks, BLOBs worked perfectly

Oh, one more thing. How would I make it execute just a single method? Let’s say that(Sorry for the RSPS reference…) I wanted to delete an item from a players inventory, when they clicked a certain button.

Hashtable<Integer, Script> scripts = new Hashtable<Integer, Script>();//Integer is the ID of the button they clicked, Script is the method/methods to call when the button is pressed.

public static boolean startScript(int buttonID) {
    if(scripts.get(buttonID) == null) {
        System.out.println("No listener for button " + buttonID + " registered.");
        return false;
    }
    scripts.get(buttonID).execute();//Let's say that for now, every button does System.out.println(buttonID);
    return true;
}

Or something along those lines, without having to program every function into it. Basically, how could I do something like this, and make it extensible?

item.description:
@Nader_H.I.M wrote:

[quote=“PeeHPee, post:16, topic:288467”][quote author=Nader[H.I.M] link=topic=381379.msg2871148#msg2871148 date=1247772486]
Either Have an Already premade class with some String called it Database String, or Create such a String Method that returns the Database String that you want and use Reflection or some ByteCode editing library such as BCEL.
[/quote]
wat?[/quote]

4. You can use any kind of Bytecode-library (BCEL as mentioned above) to manage Class-files during runtime, by for instance changing their fields values etc.

item.title: Parse a text file into a Class file?
item.dc:creator: @PeeHPee PeeHPee
item.description:
@PeeHPee wrote:

zyle1992:

Well, I was wondering if there was a way without “technically” creating a physical file. Like ry60003333 has a plugin system loading through MySQL, using BeanShell, but I have not been able to get it work on 4 different revision of java, on 3 different operating system. And I was thinking of how I could do something similar. Compiling the class and then loading it with the Class loader is viable, but would it create a physical class file, or just load it into the JVM?

you are aware that BeanShell doesn’t compile its source to java bytecode, right?

Read full topic

@Mopman wrote:

I had assumed it had to be stored as source and was going to be manipulated somehow, but if it’s going to be static then yeah, just store the binary as mitb said.

You’d probably get better answers if you described what you were doing, rather than what you think is the proper solution - we won’t bite

item.source: Parse a text file into a Class file?

item.title: Parse a text file into a Class file?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

You can store binary data in a MySQL database as the type ‘blob’, this could be pictures, or in your case a compiled class file. Then you could load it with a class loader, if you wanted to store it in the database as a source code string, then you would have to compile it first before you load it.

Read full topic

item.title: Parse a text file into a Class file?
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:7, topic:288467”]Ok, so what if I compiled it first? Like get the class loader, create the class, than compile the class?

EDIT: This is what I tried:

[code]
mysqlConnection = new MySQLConnection(“127.0.0.1”, “server”, “username”, “password”);
mysqlInput = new MySQLInputStream(mysqlConnection);

    String mysqlQuery = "SELECT commandScript FROM Commands WHERE commandName ='yell'";
    
    byte[] bytes = mysqlInput.readString(mysqlQuery).getBytes();
    
    PluginLoader loader = new PluginLoader();
    
    Class script = loader.loadPlugin("Yell", bytes, 0, bytes.length);
    Compiler.compileClass(script);
    System.out.println(script.getName());[/code]

And this is the error I got:

[quote]
Exception in thread “main” java.lang.ClassFormatError: Incompatible magic value 1885430635 in class file Yell
at java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass1(Native Method)
at java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass(ClassLoader.java:620)
at java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass(ClassLoader.java:465)
at org.zephyrion.oraculum.util.PluginLoader.loadPlugin(PluginLoader.java:5)
at org.zephyrion.oraculum.ServerEngine.main(ServerEngine.java:42)[/quote][/quote]

you have to compile it before you load it… its called a ClassLoader not a SourceLoader…

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Ok, so what if I compiled it first? Like get the class loader, create the class, than compile the class?

EDIT: This is what I tried:

[code]
mysqlConnection = new MySQLConnection(“127.0.0.1”, “server”, “username”, “password”);
mysqlInput = new MySQLInputStream(mysqlConnection);

    String mysqlQuery = "SELECT commandScript FROM Commands WHERE commandName ='yell'";
    
    byte[] bytes = mysqlInput.readString(mysqlQuery).getBytes();
    
    PluginLoader loader = new PluginLoader();
    
    Class script = loader.loadPlugin("Yell", bytes, 0, bytes.length);
    Compiler.compileClass(script);
    System.out.println(script.getName());[/code]

And this is the error I got:

Exception in thread "main" java.lang.ClassFormatError: Incompatible magic value 1885430635 in class file Yell at java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass1(Native Method) at java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass(ClassLoader.java:620) at java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass(ClassLoader.java:465) at org.zephyrion.oraculum.util.PluginLoader.loadPlugin(PluginLoader.java:5) at org.zephyrion.oraculum.ServerEngine.main(ServerEngine.java:42)

item.title: Parse a text file into a Class file?
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:5, topic:288467”]Let’s say I did something like this:

String mysqlQuery = "SELECT text FROM test WHERE testName='test1'";
MySQLInputStream mysqlInput = new MySQLInputStream(new MySQLConnection("127.0.0.1", "server", "username", "password"));//Create a new MySQLInputStream
byte[] bytes = mysqlInput.readString(mysqlQuery).getBytes();//Get the data when the query is executed, and than get the bytes.
ClassLoader loader = new ClassLoader();
Class parsed = loader.defineClass("Test", bytes, 0, bytes.length);//Define class (Not entirely sure about this, haven't really used this before)
parsed.returnString();//a Method in the class

Would that work?
Here’s the “class” I want loaded from the MySQL Database

public class Test { public String returnString() { return "String"; } }[/quote]

no because, the class being loaded needs to be an actual CLASS, in bytecode form

Read full topic

item.source: Parse a text file into a Class file?

item.title: Parse a text file into a Class file?
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Ok, I was just wondering if there was a way to turn a normal textfile(or string) into a java class file. I have a MySQL server on my comp, and I was wondering if there was a way to get the string from the database, and then somehow parse it into a normal class file.

Let’s say I had a text file(or a MySQL row value or some other string):

[code]
package org.zephyrion.oraculum;

public class ParsedFile {
public String returnString() {
return “String”;
}
}[/code]

Would it be possible to do something like this?

public void returnStringFromParsed(String text) { Class parsed = ParsingClass.parse(text); System.out.println(parsed.returnString()); }

Read full topic
item.source: Parse a text file into a Class file?
